And due to the rush of the semester, you don't even get sufficient time to work out your weakness (although no amount of time is sufficient in this competitive world). It's all about maths and proofing which I was not very familiar with (note I have a decent rank in GATECSIT). And due to the rush of the semester, you don't even get sufficient time to work out your weakness (although no amount of time is sufficient in this competitive world). It's not because it's happening in IISc, but because AI is all about maths and you gotta deal with it. So if you want a career in AI then this is the best course to opt for. The only advantage I got in this course work over other discipline students, was with Data Structure and Algorithm subject, which is a compulsory course for the AI course. But other than that you don't require much of CS skills (though we do a lot of coding here, and probably I am using my CS ninja skills there but somehow it's not noticeable to me). But if you are wondering if it is any easier for students from other disciplines ( AI is an Interdisciplinary program), then let me clear it right away NO! IT'S NOT. Even they are having their share of struggles. Sorry for diverting so much. Let's get you the taste of how difficult it gets. SCARE: You will be attending all classes regularly, but it will happen so often that you will be sitting like a dumb kid with no idea of whatsoever happening in the class (very often, so often that you can count the number of days, you completely understood, on the fingertips of your both hands... kidding! just a single hand is enough). RELIEF: The professors are so good at IISc that once you study their notes on your own, you will feel the magic of their teaching. I can't explain how beautiful their arguments of proofs can be. And eventually, you will start connecting the dots from the lectures which you never thought got into your memory. You will also be having the pleasure of fruitful discussions with some of the brightest students of India to help you with the syllabus. SCARE: Many times you will feel like, "God! I should have joined CSA, that's what I am good at, not in this ugly multivariate calculus or statistics in N-dimensions." RELIEF: You meet your CSA friends with an intent to bitch about AI. But the first thing you hear from them, "Bro, you know what! PSU was not bad either, should have joined when had the opportunity. Anyway, you AI guys are so lucky, got rid of the coding and still get to have a great placement." Then you both start crying together. Kidding! we cry in isolation. The problem is not with the course of AI or CSA but with the way we have trained our minds. Premium institutes like IISc and IITs do challenge this mindset and let you explore your potential to another level. This will hurt for sure but in the end, you will feel great about your self. I am on the verge of ending my second semester, having 8 plus CGPA, got an internship in a Big MNC, Trust me I don't regret my decision of choosing this Coursework at all. It's tough, real tough, you will feel helpless and depressed too sometimes but you will have a great company in that too and you will keep growing. You can never know if you are fit for this course, but if you get selected for it, then trust me you will fit well. I will end this answer by mentioning if you are taking the AI course then Maths will be your only friend, so be prepared to do lots of rigorous maths proofing. So if maths gives you nightmares or you start puking seeing linear algebra and probability, then this course is not for you. Other than this you will do fine. It's recommended to do an introductory course on machine learning to get the real flavor of what I am talking about ( which I never did before IISc, just did basic linear algebra from Gilbert Strang's MIT lectures). And one more thing these are just my personal opinions, and I in no sense represent my batch. So take all of these with a pinch of salt.

It is most decidedly NOT a branch of statistics, although I can understand the motivation of those who wish it were so. It’s the (engineering) attempt to build artifacts Continue Reading Here are a few things I know after spending a lifetime (over 30 years) of research and teaching in ML. It is most decidedly NOT a branch of statistics, although I can understand the motivation of those who wish it were so. Certainly, that would simplify the field and make it more coherent, but it would also eliminate many aspects of the field that make it unique. If anything, I would argue that statistics is a subfield of ML, so the inclusion goes the other way. Machine learning, is simply put, the study of learning machines (reverse the words). It’s the (engineering) attempt to build artifacts that “learn”. Part of the problem here is that we haven’t defined what “learning” is. So, a good chunk of the past 30+ years have been on trying to define what “learning” is. We’re not past figuring that out yet! The people who do ML are a curious amalgam of computer scientists, neuroscientists, statisticians, biologists, philosophers, physicists, engineers, and thinkers of various sorts. Just attend a NIPS meeting, and you’ll see why. If anything, this defines the field. As Michael Jordan (U.C. Berkeley) put it once, ML is simply defined as the set of activities of this curious mixture of people who come to meetings like NIPS. That is what makes it special.
